awd_titl_txt: CC* Compute: High-Memory Compute Resources for Maine
awd_abstract_narration:
Maine researchers are advancing the state of the art in areas including landslide prediction, hydrodynamic modelling, fluid-structure interaction and modelling the electro-chemical properties of organic molecules. Strong, scientifically compelling investigations have previously been hampered or stalled by the lack of adequate computational resources.
 
This project advances research at the University of Maine in two ways through the addition of approximately 1000 processing cores in high RAM nodes along with a growth in CEPH disk storage. It enables research to move forward in areas such as landslide prediction, coastal modelling, DNA sequencing from single strands of DNA, and high resolution modeling of the cardiovascular system. It facilitates an increase in collaboration with the Eastern Regional Network, the Open Science Grid, the Open Storage Network, and with other institutions, particularly other EPSCoR sites in the Northeast. Data and code from this grant is disseminated to the public through tools such as github and EarthCube. The increase in computational resources as a result of this project allows opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students to engage in state-of-the-art numerical modeling. By having these new resources to meet the needs of researchers, previously existing resources are utilized to offer courses for which there was not previously the capacity. Thus the instrumentation advances research and also enables the project team to better train the next generation of scientists and engineers. The research projects facilitated by this cluster all include plans to distribute, and visualize model output for relevant stakeholders.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The University of Maine System's CC* Compute project, High-Memory Compute Resources for Maine, was a multi-year effort aimed at growing and enhancing High Performance Computing (HPC) resources in the state to advance key University of Maine System (UMS) science drivers as well as enable collaboration with regional and national organizations supporting research computing. The project has greatly increased the HPC capacity available to Maine researchers and provided a computational foundation for research which has advanced science and informed public policy.

Adding HPC compute nodes to reduce researcher wait times was a central activity of the project. 18 compute servers with 36 AMD EPYC processors and a total of 1,472 CPU cores and 11,264 gigabytes of RAM were purchased and brought online as part of this project. The initial milestone of delivering 2 million CPU core hours of processing to researchers was met in 2022, and at the end of the grant period (6/30/2024) the cumulative total was more than 10.2 million core hours.

UMS researchers have benefited from the computing resources of other institutions, and a key part of this project was to collaborate with others, sharing resources to reciprocate and "pay it forward." Among other activities, UMS worked with the Open Science Grid (OSG) Consortium to make resources available to all U.S. researchers through OSPool, and to date more than 500,000 external compute jobs have run on our systems.

The computing, storage and networking resources put in place as part of this project were used by over a hundred individual UMS researchers and supported 15 peer reviewed papers. The impacts of this research can be felt in many fields of inquiry and domains of application, including the two key areas of Forestry and Marine Resources described below.

In a heavily forested state like Maine, information about the species, age and quantity of trees and other vegetation in rural lands is important to commercial and policy decisions about land use. Under the State of Maine High Resolution Land Cover project, these compute resources have been used to train and validate machine learning models that predict the relative abundance of individual tree species from high resolution satellite imagery. Statewide species predictions have been used to derive a map of forest types suitable for a wide range of uses in forest and natural resource management and applied research. Forest type data will be integrated with new land cover information provided by the NOAA Coastal-Change Analysis Program, yielding a statewide land cover and forest type map depicting 30+ categories at 10-meter resolution. Land cover data are used extensively by both public agencies and private institutions to inform land use policies and practices, and land cover data produced under this project will have spatial and thematic detail exceeding all prior state or national land cover products.

The Maine Department of Marine Resources (DMR) has responsibility for food safety in shellfish and aquaculture. In 2016, a novel species of Harmful Algal Bloom (HAB) to the Gulf of Maine forced the MEDMR to make extensive closures to shellfish harvesting and aquaculture along Maine’s coastline. These compute resources have been used to create a model forecast, made available on a public website, to help inform the MEDMR about material transport in Frenchman Bay, Maine, to help them to make management decisions surrounding HAB events in the region. Such events are a major public safety hazard, as the consumption of infected shellfish can be fatal. These closures, and those that have occurred in recent years, have a high factor of safety surrounding their duration and spatial extent, which is a source of economic uncertainty for local aquaculture farmers and shellfish harvesters. To help inform the scope of those closures and to begin to establish a scientific basis for monitoring decisions surrounding bloom events, a two-day forecast of particle transport in Frenchman Bay was created. The forecast is updated daily and relies entirely on these compute resources for operation.

This project is complete, but the compute resources, collaborative relationships with other organizations and the research products will continue to provide benefits to UMS researchers, the State of Maine, and other institutions.
